content.description:
A Chris Sharma 5.14a

Ubermensch

from

Kyle Queener

on

Vimeo

.
content.protection: Five bolts lead to a two bolt anchor
content.location: This is the overhanging arete on the East Side of the Monolith between Lard Butt and Hot Lava Lucy.

climbs.name: Wave Rider
climbs.fa: John Whitmer and Dave Hammack, December 27, 1953

content.description:
Fun traversing climb through great knobs, crossing a few routes above a steeply overhanging face below. Not good for beginners, due to pendulum potential. A really fun way to get to the summit boulder problem. Make sure and boulder up and check out the summit register!

This was the first roped climb to top out on the Monolith and was done only with a few pitons(where?). It follows the path of least resistance up the east face.  It's ascent has been confused with the first ascent of the Direct Route.
content.protection: 4 or 5 quickdraws, some shoulder length sling draws
content.location: Start at the Direct Route, and traverse right after it's first bolt, clip the anchor of Deck Chairs, then up and right to a bolt on Richnack's Revenge, to the final bolt on Monolith, Regular Route. Rap from chains with 50+m rope. tops out at Right side of summit boulder.

climbs.name: Tailspin
climbs.fa: Kelly Rich, Phoenix Vamvakias, Pat Kent, David Rubine, Jamie Castagnetto, Terri Hooson

content.description: Clip the first bolt of Foreplay and continue left traversing for four bolts before heading straight up to the anchor following three more bolts. Some loose rock can still be found but the key holds are solid enough.
content.location: This route is located left of Foreplay on the East Face of the Monolith.

content.description:
Follow the bolts up and left past a straightforward but slighlty overhanging and pumpy lower section. The crux is a tricky overhang just left of the bolts, followed by easy slightly run-out climbing to the anchor.

A bit of a one-move wonder but it's a fun overhang.
content.protection: 5 bolts, shared anchor (on the right of the boulder at the top) with Regular Route. A few of the bolts are starting to rust. Can be set up as a TR after leading Regular Route.
content.location:
Start in the middle of the wall between two large boulders about 30 feet apart and just right of a tree which grows right up to the wall. Start is about 10 feet left of the start to Regular Route.

To top-rope this climb the belayer can optionally stand on top of the boulder to the left to get a better angle for the rope. A directional through the bolt just below the overhang will help a top-roper work on the crux.

content.description:
Classic Pinnacles climbing.

Locate the start, which is the most moderate looking face climbing protected by two lead bolts.  The route takes a sharp right, pass another bolt, and turn the steep corner into a belay stance.  Fun pitch, with great position.

Ramble up the short and easier second pitch, clipping a couple bolts, enroute to the summit plateau.  Anchor is located on the NE corner of the summit boulder.
content.protection: Three lead bolts on the first pitch to a bolted anchor. Pass two bolts on the second pitch to the summit, which has a bolted anchor.  Its fairly head's up climbing with well spaced bolts.
content.location: Located near the right end of the east face of the Monolith.  Walk over to the summit boulder and rappel back to the base from the anchor on the SE side of the boulder (rap lines kinda goes down the direct route).  Single 60m rope.

climbs.name: Piton Traverse
climbs.fa: Al Baxter, John Hood and Bud Gates, February 1947

content.description:
Another historic, classic Pinnacles climb!  Start from the top of the first pitch of the Regular Route and do a short traverse to the right to the junction of the east and north faces and find a three-bolt belay.

The second pitch climbs a rising crack past several fixed pitons(AKA museum relics) to the top of the Monolith and a two bolt anchor. So much fun!
content.protection: 5-8 quick draws for the belays, pitons and small cams in case one of the pitons falls out.
content.location: Starts from the top of first pitch of the Regular Route.

climbs.name: Subterranean Tango
climbs.fa: T. Davis, M. Harrington, S. Malchelosse, 2/88

content.description:
This is a good route in the middle of the Monolith's east face.  It has 2 starts.  You can go from down below and make it 11a or you can start above skipping the first 2 bolts.  If you don't go down into the subterranean bit, it goes at 10a or so.

Follow an appealing face with neat, embedded rocks protruding from the matrix.  Pass 7 or 9 bolts.  There is a runout bit near the top above the last bolt.
content.protection: 7-9 bolts, depending on the start, and a 3 bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is in the middle of the east face of the Monolith.  It is just right of

Post Orgasmic Depression

.

content.description:
This is a Pinnacles classic.  Odd name.

Ascend an aesthetic, vertical face on small embedded rocks in a conglomerate face.  Ascend a small right-facing dihedral.  Pass 7 bolts with the crux being above the 4th bolt.  3 bolts anchor.
content.location:
On the East face of The Monolith, between

Foreplay

/Several Small Species and Indirect Traverse/

Hawaiian Noises

.

content.description:
An historic and enjoyable route.  Climb the first pitch of the Regular Route and belay. The first, short, pitch of this route traverses right(north) on the ledge to the corner at the junction of the east and north faces where there are three bolts for a belay.

The second pitch climbs directly up the corner past one bolt to a two-bolt anchor on top of the Monolith.

To descend, walk over to the east face and descend via one of the multiple anchors on this wall.
content.protection: 5-6 quick draws for the bolts and belays.
content.location: Begins at the top of the first pitch of the Regular Route

content.description:
Climb up the slightly-overhanging lower section to the overhang on good holds.

After the second bolt, angle right using a large side pull and throw a big right hand to the large rock protruding just below the overhang. It's easily big enough to hang with two hands (though can be slippery). Pull over the overhang on this, grabbing whatever you can above it until you can mantle over it. Can be mossy/dirty right above the large block hold.

Easy climbing to the top after this spectacular crux.
content.protection:
This climb is best top-roped, but can be lead with some risk of a nasty fall at the crux. 4 (or 5) bolts to a shared bolted anchor with Regular Route and Richnak's Revenge.

The crux is poorly protected, the bolts are really meant for Richnak's Revenge to the left and are well below and left of the crux overhang. A fall here (and this is the most difficulty climbing section requiring a dynamic move) would lead to a large whipper, possibly involving the nearby tree branches or even the boulder below the start of Wave Rider.
content.location: Shares bolts with Richnak's Revenge and is mostly the same climb, only going right after the second bolt to get over the overhang in a different spot.

content.description: A 25-30 ft boulder problem leads into the top half of Cantaloupe Death (5.10 climbing). Probably want to "stick clip" the first draw as its not a great spot to fall off.
content.protection: 6 bolts, shares the top 2 with Cantaloupe Death
content.location: This is the route starting immediately down and right of Cantaloupe Death.

content.description:
This is a nice, little sport route between

Post Orgasmic Depression

and

Subterranean Tango

.  It ascends a nice face with embedded rocks poking out of a matrix.

The guidebook notes it was originally led going to the 2nd bolt of Indirect Traverse.  Done this way, it is a bit of climbing to the 1st pro.  It can be done going to the 1st bolt of Indirect Traverse.

There is a reachy section mid-height and a runout going to the anchors.

Any ideas about the origin of the name?
content.location:
This route is on the east face of the Monolith between

Post Orgasmic Depression

and

Subterranean Tango

.

content.description: Start in the Regular route. Past the 3rd bolt on the ledge, move directly up and to the left instead of continuing to the right.
content.protection: Six Protection bolts to a two-bolt anchor.

climbs.name: Foreplay
climbs.fa: T. Davis, K. Rich, D. Rubine, R. Rubine, 12/88.

content.description:
This is a steep climb, described in the guidebook as "spectacular" which certainly draws the eye.  It seems to climb steeper than it looks.

Ascend a slightly-overhanging face past 8 bolts.  The guidebook notes it was originally climbed without the first bolt.
content.location:
This is on the far left side of the east face of the Monolith.  It is left of

Post Orgasmic Depression

& Several Small Species.

content.description: The crux is getting to the second bolt. Short but stout. One of the best 5.11s at Pinnacles National Park.
content.location: First line of bolts to the left of Cantaloupe Death.

content.description: Pre-clip the first bolt from the boulder, and then start from the ground just left of the starting holds for 'Hot Lava Lucy". Cool lock offs on small knobs for 20 feet connects back into "Cantalope Death". A spot is nice to stop a swing in the event of a fall near the start.
content.protection: Eight bolts to a two-bolt anchor.

content.description:
A great route, but, no beginner lead and quite possibly x-rated (R+ in the guidebook).  Blowing it to the first and/or second bolt would have severe consequences.

That said, fun climbing. Classic Pinnacles.

Lean over, start up the committing moves to the first bolt, and keep a darn cool head.  Or, TR it by climbing another route to the summit plateau.
content.protection:
4 very well spaced lead bolts.  Scary!

Makes sense that some semblance of belay anchor take place as a fall prior to the first bolt would have dire consequences for both the leader and belayer.  Maybe take a set of gear and put something bomber in.
content.location: Starts on the pedestal just north of Lunch Rock.  Rappel route from anchor bolts on the SE corner of the summit boulder.

climbs.name: Cantaloupe Death
climbs.fa: Mark Chapman, Ed Barry, John Yabo Yablonsky 1989

content.description: Very fun lean-across-and-swing leads to some of the best pinn's knob pulling. The lean-across may seem intimidating, but after committed is easy.
